heading: tech, net stocks set pace
subheading: new mergers and partnerships make for another banner day among the usual suspects. and broadcast.com becomes a force to be reckoned with. by david lazarus.
author: david lazarus
text: tech and internet stocks zoomed higher in mid-afternoon trading monday, boosted by word of some heavyweight mergers and tie-ups. and news of a two-for-one stock split catapulted broadcast.com to even loftier heights. keep an eye on lucent technologies. the telecom gearmaker is spending almost us$1.5 billion on a software company, but a much, much larger deal is said to be around the corner.the broader market was mixed. the dow jones industrial average shed 63.33 points to 9579.99, and the s&p 500 was 16.65 lower at 1258.44. the nasdaq composite index gained 9.70 to 2354.11, and the wired index was up 2.99 at 631.61."partnering is what it's all about," said william kurtz, an analyst with hg wellington & co. "everyone is trying to make the best arrangements before the other guys do."case in point: compaq computer (cpq) will fork over $220 million in ready cash to acquire electronic retailer shopping.com (ibuy). the deal is intended to bolster compaq's altavista portal with a more substantial e-commerce component. the pc maker advanced $1.50 to $46.88, while shopping.com soared $5.34, or 41 percent, to $18.53.there's nothing new about computer manufacturers cutting marketing deals with leading portals and internet service providers. but when the two most eminent names in their respective industries climb into bed together, that catches people's attention.yahoo (yhoo) vaulted $42.38, or 12 percent, to $386 after announcing an accord with international business machines (ibm) for big blue's aptiva pcs to feature built-in links to the portal's services. the upside for yahoo was seen as being significantly higher than for ibm, which only gained 69 cents to $188.25. but investors are also looking ahead to yahoo posting an expected quarterly profit of 16 cents a share on tuesday.broadcast.com (bcst) -- go figure. the online media outfit went ballistic on friday for no better reason than having given a respectable performance at an investment conference in new york. now it's up another $66.50, or 34 percent, at $264 on word of a two-for-one stock split. the split will affect shareholders of record as of 1 february.etrade group (egrp) climbed $10.63, or 16 percent, to $78.25 even as it reported a quarterly loss of 23 cents a diluted share, blaming the shortfall on recent marketing efforts to woo new customers. but analysts had been expecting a loss of 30 cents, so the company was deemed to be performing up to snuff.elsewhere on the net, infoseek (seek) surged $13.81, or 25 percent, to $68.94, and lycos (lcos), soon-to-be parent of wired news, was $10.13 higher at $101.88. amazon.com (amzn) accelerated $11.25 to $171.50, and america online (aol) jumped $10.25 to $156.75 as merrill lynch raised its price target for the stock to $195 a share.traders were wary of lucent, (lu) saying it will pay nearly $1.5 billion for kenan systems, a maker of customer-service applications, sending the company's stock down $3.25 to $112. if this price tag looked a bit steep, how will the market react to lucent shelling out $16 billion for network-equipment producer ascend communications? the financial times said such a deal is likely to be announced this week.rumors of a lucent-ascend marriage have been making the rounds for months, and the two companies do look like a good fit. combining lucent's background in phone systems with ascend's savvy for data networks would make a merged entity a mighty influential rival to leader-of-the-pack cisco systems (csco). for what it's worth, cisco fell $2.50 to $104.19 as speculation about lucent's intentions mounted.among other tech movers, intel (intc) gained $7.88 to $137.56 as lehman brothers reiterated a "buy" rating for the chipmaker's stock. intel is expected to report quarterly profit of $1.07 a share tuesday, although some on the street already are whispering that a higher number will be revealed.lastly, mickey mouse owes john travolta a debt of thanks. disney (dis) rose $1.38 to $33.94 after its new legal thriller, a civil action, topped the box-office chart with an opening weekend of $14.5 million in tickets sold.
